newsitem.title: USA: Stocks fall on profit-taking after election rally.
newsitem.headline: Stocks fall on profit-taking after election rally.

text.p: Stocks fell Friday as investors took profits after a post-election rally, but some analysts said the market could move higher next week.

At 1 p.m. EST, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 9.32 points to 6,196.72. The blue-chip index rallied 97 points to set a record Wednesday, then rose 28 points to a record 6,206.04 on Thursday.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 13-9 on active volume of 230 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index fell 2.40 points to 1,251.74.

"After the big move in stocks and bonds, and bonds in particular, you have to expect some profit-taking, especially when the long bond yield went down to 6.5 percent," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 20/32 to yield 6.58 percent, up from 6.54 percent at Thursday's close.
He said the excuse for stocks' weakness could be found in Friday's release of September wholesale inventories, which fell 1.3 percent after a 0.1 percent drop in August.
More importantly, the stocks/sales ratio -- a measure of consumer demand -- came in at 1.27, the lowest since a 1.27 reading in August of 1990.

"This hints that production will have to be increased at the wholesale level to replenish stocks," Johnson said. "That's the excuse that touched off some profit-taking in the stock and bond markets. The stocks that have been real winners -- like the semi (conductors) and regional banks, computers and electric utilities -- are the losers today."
Johnson said stocks that went up are "hitting a wall today. Investors will go home for the weekend, brush themselves off and come back for another fight on Monday."
Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd., said the market was undergoing a normal consolidation and, in fact, wanted to move higher.

"This is a much overdue consolidation after two screaming up days," Bleier said. "There is obviously a desire to own stocks just below where the market is. I think the market is within 1 or 2 percent of a near-term top before we see further consolidation."
Big losers included Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc., which fell 3-1/2 to 11-1/8 after Morgan Stanley cut its rating on the stock to neutral from strong buy.

Technology stocks gave back some of their recent gains, with Intel Corp. down 7/8 at 121-1/4, Cisco Systems down 1-1/8 at 63-3/8, Microsoft Corp. down 3/4 at 142-3/4 and International Business Machines Corp. down 5/8 at 133-1/8.
Iomega Corp., which topped the NYSE most active list on its first day of NYSE trading, was down 1/2 at 24-7/8.
Conrail Inc. rallied 2-1/8 to 95-1/8 as the bidding war for the company between Norfolk Southern Corp. and CSX Corp. brought a sweetened offer from Norfolk.

America Online Inc. rose 1-1/4 to 26 after Lehman Brothers reiterated a buy rating on the stock. The company reported a first-quarter loss, but Lehman analyst Brian Oakes said he was pleased with signs that momentum was picking up.
